questions.question: Which helping verb is used with the subject "I" in the present time?
questions.explanation: The helping verb "am" is used with the subject "I" in the present time, e.g., "I am a student."

questions.question: She ______ a talented artist.
questions.explanation: "She" is a singular subject, and "is" here is used to describe a lasting characteristic.

questions.question: He ______ never been to Paris.
questions.explanation: "He" is a singular subject, and "has" is used with singular subjects.

questions.question: Which helping verb is used with the subject "you" in the present time?
questions.explanation: The helping verb "are" is used with the subject "you" in the present time, e.g., "You are a good friend."

questions.question: They ______ playing outside when it started raining.
questions.explanation: "They" is plural, and "were" helps form the past time.

questions.question: She _______ finished her assignment before dinner.
questions.explanation: The helping verb "has" is used with the singular subject (she, he, it).

questions.question: ______ (Am/Is/Are) you coming to the party?
questions.explanation: "You" is typically considered a plural pronoun in questions, and "are" is used with plural subjects.

questions.question: The team _____ won the championship game.
questions.explanation: The helping verb "have" is used with the singular subject "The team" in the present time.

questions.question: We ______ a great time at the beach.
questions.explanation: "Had" shows something that happened in the past (e.g.: yesterday, last month, last year). It is used with both singular and plural nouns and pronouns.

questions.question: The flowers _____ bloomed in the garden.
questions.explanation: The helping verb "have" is used with the plural subject "The flowers" in the present time.

questions.question: She ______ (was/were) tired after a long day at work.
questions.explanation: "She" is singular, and "was" helps describe a state of being in the past.

questions.question: "Had" can be used as a helping verb with both singular and plural subjects.
questions.explanation: "Had" can be used as a helping verb with both singular and plural subjects in the past time.

questions.question: It ______ raining heavily right now.
questions.explanation: "It" is a singular pronoun, and it helps describe the current state of the weather.

questions.question: He __________ visited his nephews last summer.
questions.explanation: "Had" tells about something that happened before another thing in the past time.

questions.question: She ______ (am/is/are) always on time for appointments.
questions.explanation: "She" is singular, and "is" helps describe a habitual characteristic.

questions.question: By the time the concert started, the fans _____ waiting for hours.
questions.explanation: The subject "fans" is plural, so we use the plural form of the verb. The correct sentence is: "By the time the concert started, the fans were waiting for hours."

questions.question: Which helping verb is used with the subject "he" in the past time?
questions.explanation: We use "was" with singular nouns, the pronouns I, HE, SHE and IT.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses the helping verb "am"?
options: I am going to the store later.
They am students at the university.
questions.explanation: The helping verb "am" is used with the subject "I" in the present time.

questions.question: They _______ (had/ has) finished their piano lessons before playing outside.
questions.explanation: "Had" shows something that happened in the past (e.g.: yesterday, last month, last year). It is used with both singular and plural nouns and pronouns.

questions.question: Identify the sentence that correctly uses the helping verb "were":
options: The students were studying for the exam.
The book were on the shelf.
I were happy to see you.
questions.explanation: The helping verb "were" was used with the plural subject "The students" in the past time.
